title: The Bystander Effect: The science of empathy

options.label: A
options.text: The bystander effect is a phenomenon where individuals in a group are more likely to help someone in need because they feel a sense of responsibility.

options.label: B
options.text: The bystander effect is a phenomenon where individuals in a group are less likely to help someone in need because they assume someone else will take care of it.

options.label: C
options.text: The bystander effect is a phenomenon where individuals in a group are more likely to take credit for someone else's actions.

options.label: D
options.text: The bystander effect is a phenomenon where individuals in a group are less likely to take responsibility for their own actions.

options.text: Because they felt a sense of responsibility to help.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they were more likely to take a leadership role.

options.label: B
options.text: Helping someone in a group is more likely to lead to a sense of responsibility.

options.label: C
options.text: Helping someone when you are alone is more likely to lead to a sense of responsibility.

options.label: D
options.text: Helping someone in a group is less likely to lead to a sense of responsibility.
